resources.string: This should only take a few seconds.
Please state your query in English.
Please state your query in Japanese.
Please select the text for OCR
Current Android version is too low
OCR engine was not initialized. Trying again…
A long processing time may mean the OCR engine is having trouble deciphering the image and will result in random OCR text. In such case you should try using a better picture.
Please wait until the OCR data finishes downloading.
Successfully installed data from Downloads Folder.
Please select and crop Japanese text. For best results, select a FEW symbols occupying a large area in a clear picture. Otherwise the OCR engine may not work properly.
Please select and crop English text. For best results, select a FEW words occupying a large area in a clear picture. Otherwise the OCR engine may not work properly.
Sorry, it appears your phone does not have Speech-To-Text functionality. Redirecting to relevant resources…
Please select how you want to download the required Japanese Optical Character Recognition data (approx. 40MB).
Please select how you want to download the required English Optical Character Recognition data (approx. 20MB).
Not found in local dictionary. Searching in other sources…
Please enter an English/Japanese word. Complete words will yield the best results, but word fragments will also do.
Looking for results online, please wait…

In order to keep the search time reasonable, not all verb tenses are included. As such, please observe the following rules: 

When looking up less common conjugations (e.g. tabesaseta), you may have to convert the verb to present tense (tabesaseru). 

If you're searching for a compound verb (e.g. tabete ikimasu), you must first convert the second verb to its dictionary form (tabete iku). 

If you're searching for a verb addition (e.g. taberu bakari), use the <DICT> search on "bakari" to look up the corresponding grammar rule. 

The <DICT> search also covers alternate Romaji or Kanji spellings for a variety of verbs (in dictionary form). The <CONJ> search only looks up conjugations for the most common Romaji spelling and Kanji interpretation of each verb.
You can also enter an English verb in ing/infinitive form.
Check the rules below for hints.

Hint: 
Use an apostrophe (') after "n" to ensure its transliteration to "ん". 

Also note that this app uses a variation of Kunrei-Shiki romanization, where for example "う" is always transliterated to "u", and "づ" is always transliterated to "du".

Hint: 
Enter a Kanji into the Search bar and click on the decomposition (好 > 女+子) button in order to get its decompositions. 
 
The decompositions are evaluated using a heavily modified and corrected version of Gavin Grover's decomposition database (see cjkdecomp.codeplex.com).

Japanese Toolbox is a set of reference tools designed to make learning Japanese much more efficient, by giving quick answers to questions on difficult subjects such as grammar, verb conjugations and Kanji decompositions. Most of the app\'s functions require no Internet connectivity.
The app includes the following tools:
- A local dictionary of frequent Japanese words and expressions, complete with grammar rules (DICT button). If there is Internet access then online results are added.
- A reverse verb conjugation finder (CONJ button). If you search for a conjugation shared by many verbs (such as "saseru"), the search results will be limited to 50 verbs.

- A Kanji composer (女+子 ⇒ 好 button) where you can find all Kanjis based through their radicals and/or components and/or general structure. Note that users of Android versions below Marshmallow may experience "blank symbols" instead of Japanese characters in some cases.
- A Kanji decomposer (好 ⇒ 女+子 button) where you can get the meaning and readings of all of the components in a given Kanji.
- A Text-To-Speech function (speaker button) so that you may listen to your query in English or in Japanese. You can choose the speech language in the Settings menu.
- A Speech-To-Text function (microphone button) for Japanese or English speech. You can choose the speech recognition language in the Settings menu.
- A Image-To-Text function (camera button) for Japanese or English scripts. You can choose the script recognition language in the Settings menu.
Credits - I built JapaneseToolbox\'s local database and search algorithms on my own, but also used the following open-source tools:
- The OCR engine is provided by the Tesseract open-source project (supported by Google).
- The Text-To-Speech and Speech-To-Text functions are based on Google APIs.
- The camera tools are provided by the ArthurHub library (https://github.com/ArthurHub/Android-Image-Cropper).
- Image sharpening is provided by Pete Houston\'s algorithm (https://xjaphx.wordpress.com/2011/06/22/image-processing-sharpening-image/).
- The CJK character decompositions database is a heavily modified and corrected version of the cjkdecomp database by Gavin Grover (https://github.com/amake/cjk-decomp) - see disclaimer*.

If you have any comments or feedback, or encountered a bug, you're welcome to post them at japanesetoolboxapp@gmail.com.

I built JapaneseToolbox on my spare time out of love for the Japanese language and to help people learn Japanese faster. The app will always remain FREE, with no ads whatsoever, and the user information you enter in the app through the query input, Speech-To-Text and Image-To-Text functions is in no way used for purposes other than the services provided in the app.

The source code for the project is freely available at https://github.com/blarom/JapaneseToolbox.
You can copy the code to your heart's content! I encourage the free sharing of knowledge, and if you want to build an app with similar functions, you're more than welcome to do so. Just don't forget to mention me as the source, I spent a lot of time developing these tools :)

*disclaimer for cjkdecomp:

Access to the camera is needed for detection
This application cannot run because it does not have the camera permission. The application will now exit.
Ocr dependencies cannot be downloaded due to low device storage
